   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: Ms. [**Known lastname 10607**] is a 60 y.o. F with CAD s/p IMI, CHF
   with EF 20%, SLE, scleroderma, severe pulmonary HTN, COPD on home O2,
   who presents with R hip fracture as an OSH transfer for surgery, s/p R
   ORIF and transferred to MICU for hypotension.
   .
   # Hypotension: Pt hypotensive in PACU to 70-80s and needed peripheral
   neosynephrine to maintain pressures. Given poor urine output,
   concentrated appearing urine, cold and dry extremities, likely
   hypovolemic.  Hematocrit has been stable prior to and after surgery.
   Less likely sepsis given afebrile, lactate not elevated, but cannot r/o
   given recent surgical manipulation.
   - place CVL for access
   - serial lactates
   - follow central venous sat
   - monitor CVP and aim for goal 15-20
   - bolus for UOP of goal 30 cc/hour
   - pressors if not responsive to IVF boluses for goal MAP>65
   - monitor Hct and transfuse if bleeding, hemodynamically unstable, or
   Hct<21
   - send blood cultures
   .
   # R Hip Fracture: s/p R ORIF on [**2167-10-8**]
   - appreciate ortho recs
   - will touch base regarding lovenox dosing in AM - will need to talk
   with pain team as epidural in place
   - pain control with IV medication prn and lidocaine patch
   - f/u pain consult recs - epidural in place
   - clindamycin 600 mg IV x 2 doses per ortho
   .
   # C. difficile infection: OSH admission with + c. diff. CT scan at OSH
   with pancolitis.  ID recs at OSH: prolonged PO vanco taper 125mg PO QID
   X 14 days, 125mg PO BID X 1, 125mg daily x 1 week, 125mg QOD x 1 week,
   125mg q3 days x 2 weeks, then stop.
   - will continue PO vancomycin at 125mg PO QID
   - monitor stool output
   .
   # Systolic CHF: hold lisinopril, metoprolol, lasix given hypotension
   .
   # CAD s/p PCI to LCx:
   - continue ASA, statin
   - hold beta blocker given hypotension
   - hold Plavix for upcoming surgery given that PCI was in [**2164**]
   .
   # Hypoxia: likely multifactorial with COPD at baseline and poor
   pulmonary toilet with recent hospitalizations
   - continue Advair
   - ipratropium and albuterol nebs
   - incentive spirometer s/p surgery
   .
   # SLE: continue hydroxychloroquine
   .
   # Pulmonary Hypertension: will continue Revatio and Tracleer in AM -
   family to bring
   .
   # Neuralgia: hold amitryptline and gabapentin due to sedating effects
   .
   # FEN: IVFs / replete lytes prn / NPO except meds
   # PPX: home PPI, heparin SQ, bowel regimen
   # ACCESS: RIJ
   # CODE: FULL (confirmed)
   # CONTACT:  [**Name (NI) 186**] [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 10607**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10608**] (cell); [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10609**]
   (home); Daughter [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Known lastname 10607**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10610**], ICU Consent signed
   # DISPO: ICU

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
Ms. [**Known lastname 10607**], a 60-year-old female with multiple comorbidities including CAD s/p PCI to LCx, CHF with EF 20%, SLE, scleroderma, severe pulmonary HTN, and COPD, was admitted to the ICU for hypotension following right hip surgery. She has a history of Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection and was previously treated with oral vancomycin at OSH. 

The patient is currently intubated and receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin and cefepime. She is also receiving Flagyl for suspected septic shock due to C. diff. An echo showed hypokinesis of the right ventricle, which is an old finding compared to her previous records. The patient's allergies include penicillins, sulfa medications, and aspirin.

The patient has been given two units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and 5.5 liters of intravenous fluids for hypotension and poor urine output. The pain catheter has been removed, and she is receiving sedation with fentanyl and midazolam.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.3°C, heart rate of 80 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 104/57 mmHg to 129/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and

   with EF 20%, SLE, scleroderma, severe pulmonary HTN, COPD on home O2,
   who presents with R hip fracture as an OSH transfer for surgery, s/p R
   ORIF and transferred to MICU for hypotension.
   .
   # Hypotension: Current differential include Cdiff sepsis vs hypovolemia
   (seen with LVOF obstruction on echo) vs cardiogenic shock. Has been off
   pressors since yesterday afternoon and has responded to fluids.
   Lactates have been low and SVO2 high. Has been afebrile for 24 hours.
   CVPs hard to monitor with RV failure (which is old.) Also hct
   downtrending with unclear source of bleeding, received 2units PRBCs
   yesterday.
   - cont IVF bolus MAP>55, levophed if needed
   -IVF for low UOP
   -cont broad coverage with Vanc/Cef/IV flagyl and PO Vanc
   -trend hct
   .

   needs and known CHF
   -wean vent, on pressure support
   -may require diuresis for vent weaning
   -restart revatio
   -f/u am CXR
   .
   # R Hip Fracture: s/p R ORIF on [**2167-10-8**], pain d/ced epidural catheter

The differential diagnosis for her hypotension includes Clostridium difficile (C. diff) sepsis, hypovolemia, and cardiogenic shock.    60yo woman with a h/o CAD s/p IMI, CHF with EF 20%, SLE, scleroderma,
   severe pulmonary HTN, COPD on home oxygen (2L NC), multiple episodes of
   C diff, meningitis in [**3-9**], prior SBO s/p surgery, who presented with a
   right hip fracture now s/p right ORIF yesterday with post-operative
   hypotension and hypoxia.
 HIP FRACTURE (FEMORAL NECK FRACTURE, FEMUR)
   S/p repair yesterday was reportedly uncomplicated. Standard post-op
   care from an Ortho perspective. Will touch base with Pain regarding
   d/c
ing the epidural. Will decrease her Dilaudid dose to 0.125mg given
   she is quite somnolent this morning.
 .H/O C. DIFFICILE INFECTION (C DIFF, CDIFF COLITIS, CLOSTRIDIUM
   DIFFICILE)
   She is on PO Vanc; will continue this for the time being. Her abdominal
   exam is mildly to moderately tender; it
s unclear what her baseline is.
   Will add Flagyl IV for additional coverage.
 HYPOXEMIA
   She has underlying severe lung disease from her scleroderma
   particularly given that she is on oxygen at home. She currently appears
   volume replete clinically in as that her SvO2 is >90% and her CVP is
   >15. Would hold on further aggressive volume repletion at this time.
   Would restart Bosentan; hold Sildenafil while she is on pressors. She
   may need to get re-intubated given her tenuous clinical status.
 HYPOTENSION (NOT [**Date Range **])
 FEVER, UNKNOWN ORIGIN (FUO, HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA)
   Her hypotension is likely multifactorial in nature. She is on a small
   dose of Levophed currently. In the setting of her surgery yesterday,
   volume depletion is a likely consideration both from intra-operative
   blood loss and insensible losses. However, since arriving in th MICU
   she has had a persistent fever which implies some degree of
   distributive hypotension. Reassuringly her lactate was ~1, which does
   argue against significant tissue hypoxia. In addition, her EF is
   markedly low implying a cardiogenic component. Finally, PE is a
   consideration in a post-op patient. TTE won
t be particularly helpful
   in assessing this possibility as her RV was essentially
blown
 on her
   [**10-8**] (described as
overloaded and hypokinetic.
 To further clarify
   her hemodynamics, a TTE this morning will be helpful in ensuring that
   she hasn
t had an interval decrease in her EF or marked changes in her
   pulmonary hypertension. Will cycle her SvO2. With regard to her fever
   and the concern for distributive [**Last Name (LF) 281**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] f/u cultures. She needs
   empiric coverage for health care associated infections; as such we will
   add Vanc IV, Flagyl IV and Cefepime IV to her PO Vanc for broad
   coverage while cultures are pending. Provide volume resuscitation in an
   effort to take off her pressors. Will check post-op LFTs, get an
   up-right KUB and have a low threshold for pursuing further work-up of
   abdominal processes. Would check a random cortisol, TSH and consider
   checking her cardiac output with a Vigileo.
 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE
   Holding her ACE-I, beta-blocker, and continue aspirin and Lipitor.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old woman with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), previous inferior myocardial infarction (IMI), congestive heart failure (CHF) with an ejection fraction (EF) of 20%, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), scleroderma, severe pulmonary hypertension (PHTN), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) on home oxygen, multiple episodes of Clostridium difficile infection (C. diff), and a history of small bowel obstruction (SBO) post-surgery.

The patient presented with a right hip fracture and was admitted to an orthopedic surgical hospital (OSH) for surgical correction. She underwent right open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) yesterday but experienced post-operative hypotension and hypoxia. She was subsequently transferred to the medical intensive care unit (MICU).

The patient's current medical conditions include:

1. Hip fracture (femoral neck fracture, femur) - S/p repair yesterday without technical complications.
2. History of C. difficile infection - Currently on PO Vanc and will continue this for the time being. Abdominal exam is mildly to moderately tender.
3. Hypoxemia - Underlying severe lung disease from scleroderma, particularly given that she is on oxygen at home. SvO2 is >90% and CVP is >15.
4. Hypotension - Likely

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 60-year-old woman with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20%, systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, severe pulmonary hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and multiple episodes of Clostridium difficile infection. She presented with a right hip fracture and was admitted to an outside hospital for Clostridium difficile pan-colitis. She was discharged on oral vancomycin. Upon returning home, she had a mechanical fall and was found to have a broken hip. She was referred to this hospital for surgical correction. She underwent right open reduction internal fixation (ORIF) yesterday afternoon. The operation was without technical complications. However, there have been several hours of low to no urine output. In the post-anesthesia care unit (PACU), she was hypoxic post-extubation requiring a face mask, hypotensive requiring neostigmine (peripheral), and an arterial line and peripheral IV were placed. She was transferred to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for further care. On arrival to the MICU, she was groggy, without pain, and oriented to place but not time/year.

Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and acute shock. He has a history of C. difficile infection, hip fracture, and an unknown origin fever. The patient is currently intubated on CPAP/PSV with an FiO2 of 50% and has been receiving various antibiotics since admission. His vital signs show a slightly elevated temperature, normal heart rate, low blood pressure, normal respiratory rate, and high oxygen saturation. The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin levels, normal platelet count, and slightly elevated creatinine levels. The patient's medical history includes a femoral neck fracture, C. difficile infection, and previous admissions for similar conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is already experiencing respiratory failure, which may worsen if there are further complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or aspiration.

2. Septic Shock: Given the patient's acute shock and known infections (C. difficile, fever of unknown origin), there is a risk of septic shock developing if the infections progress or spread.

3. Hip Fracture Complications: The patient's hip fracture could lead to complications such as non-union, malunion, or pressure ulcers if not properly managed.

4. C. difficile Infection: The patient's history of C. difficile infection increases the risk of recurrence or worsening of symptoms if appropriate

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old woman with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20%, systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, severe pulmonary hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), multiple episodes of Clostridium difficile infection, and a prior small bowel obstruction that required surgery. She presented with a right hip fracture, which was surgically corrected yesterday without technical complications. However, the patient experienced post-operative hypotension and hypoxia, leading to her admission to the medical ICU.

The patient's current condition includes hypoxemia, likely due to her severe lung disease and oxygen dependency at home. She also has hypotension, possibly resulting from volume depletion, distributive hypotension (fever), cardiogenic factors (low EF), and potential pulmonary embolism. Additionally, she has a fever of unknown origin, which may indicate an infection or another underlying cause.

The patient is on several medications, including vancomycin, cefepime, Flagyl, fentanyl, midazolam, heparin, omeprazole, and hydromorphone. She has multiple allergies to penicillins, sulfa, and aspirin. The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 80 bpm, blood pressure of 104/57 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99% on supplemental oxygen. Her CVP is 16 mmHg, and her total fluid input/output balance shows a positive balance of 4,743 mL.

Laboratory results indicate a white blood cell count of 12.1 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.7 g/dL, platelet count of 273 K/uL, blood glucose of 101 mg/dL, sodium of 137 mEq/L, potassium of 4.2 mEq/L, chloride of 104 mEq/L, total bilirubin of 2.4 mg/dL, creatinine of 0.7 mg/dL, and troponin-T of 0.05 ng/mL. The patient's arterial blood gas analysis shows a pH of 7.31, partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 154 mmHg, and partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 26 mmHg.

   Ms. [**Known lastname 10607**] is a 60 y.o. F with CAD s/p IMI, CHF with EF 20%, SLE,

 cardiogenic vs

   .

   (seen with LVOF obstruction on echo) vs cardiogenic shock. Has been off
   pressors for approximately 36 hours and has responded to fluids.
   Lactates have been low and SVO2 high. Low grade fever in last 24 hours.

   - incentive spirometer s/p surgery
   .

She presented with a right hip fracture and was admitted to the hospital. She underwent right open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) surgery yesterday but experienced post-operative hypotension and hypoxia.

She has a history of severe lung disease due to scleroderma and is on home oxygen. She is sedated and unable to follow commands but nods yes when asked if she can hear.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old woman with a history of coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20%, systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, severe pulmonary hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease on home oxygen, multiple episodes of Clostridium difficile infection, and a previous small bowel obstruction surgery. She presented with a right hip fracture and was admitted to the hospital. She underwent right open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) surgery yesterday but experienced post-operative hypotension and hypoxia. She is currently intubated and sedated.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hip Fracture (Femoral Neck Fracture, Femur): The patient had a right hip fracture and underwent surgery for ORIF. Post-operative complications such as infection, non-union, or implant-related issues may occur.
2. Clostridium Difficile Infection (C. Diff, C. difficile colitis, Clostridium difficile): The patient has a history of multiple episodes of C. diff infection. She is currently on PO Vanc and will continue this for the time being. Additional coverage with Flagyl IV has been added.

She presented with a right hip fracture and was admitted to an outside hospital for Clostridium difficile pan-colitis. She was discharged on oral Vancomycin. Upon returning home, she had a mechanical fall and was found to have a broken hip. She was referred to Hospital1 for surgical correction and underwent right open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) yesterday afternoon. She came to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for further care. On arrival, she was groggy, without pain, and oriented to place but not time/year.

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old woman with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20%, systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, severe pulmonary hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) on home oxygen, multiple episodes of Clostridium difficile infection, and a prior small bowel obstruction status post surgery. She presented with a right hip fracture and was admitted to another hospital for Clostridium difficile pancolitis and was discharged on oral vancomycin. Upon returning home, she had a mechanical fall and was found to have a broken hip. She was referred to Hospital1 for surgical correction and underwent open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) yesterday afternoon. However, the operation was without technical complications. 

Postoperatively, the patient experienced low to no urine output, hypoxia requiring a face mask, and hypotension requiring neostigmine (peripheral). An arterial line and peripheral IV were placed. She came to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for further care. On arrival, she was groggy, without pain, and oriented to place but not time/year.

The patient has a history of allergies to penicillins, sulfa (sulfonamide antibiotics), and aspirin. The last doses of antibiotics she received were clindamycin on 10/9/2167 at 09:46 AM, cefepime on 10/11/2167 at 12:00 AM, metronidazole on 10/11/2167 at 04:00 AM, and vancomycin on 10/11/2167 at 07:30 AM.

Her vital signs include a maximum temperature of 38.1 degrees Celsius (100.5 degrees Fahrenheit), current temperature of 37.6 degrees Celsius (99.7 degrees Fahrenheit), heart rate of 111 beats per minute (95-113 bpm), blood pressure of 116/63 mmHg (81/59-74/90 mmHg), respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute (25-32 bpm), and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP)/pressure support ventilation (PSV) with a tidal volume (Vt) of 385 mL (232-459 mL), peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 11 cmH2O, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 60%, respiratory system compliance index (RSBI) of 80, and partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2) / fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 158.

The patient's laboratory values include a hemoglobin (Hb) level of 9.6 g/dL, leukocyte (WBC) count of 12.1 thousand cells/microliter (13.2-12.3 thousand cells/microliter), platelet (Plt) count of 273 thousand cells/microliter (308-298 thousand cells/microliter), creatinine (Cr) level of 0.7 mg/dL (0.8-0.9 mg/dL), troponin-T level of 0.05 ng/mL (489/8/0.05 ng/mL), lactate level of 0.9 mmol/L, and blood glucose level of 101 mg/dL (81 mg/dL).

The patient's assessment and plan include a diagnosis of hip fracture, post-operative hypotension and hypoxia, Clostridium difficile infection, hypoxemia, hypotension (not in shock), and fever of unknown origin. The patient is being treated with oral vancomycin for Clostridium difficile infection, restarting sildenafil and bosphentan later today or tomorrow if blood pressure remains stable, holding angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE-I), beta-blocker, and continuing aspirin and atorvastatin (Lipitor). The patient's pain is improving, and there is no current concern for worsening colitis.

The patient is a 62-year-old male with a history of respiratory failure, other shock, fever of unknown origin, hip fracture, Clostridium difficile infection, hypoxemia, and hypotension. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. He is also on multiple IV medications including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and stress ulcer prophylaxis. The patient's vital signs are stable with a temperature of 37.6 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 111 beats per minute, blood pressure of 116/63 mmHg, respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. 

Based on the information provided, potential medical complications that can arise include ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and further complications related to the hip fracture. It is important to closely monitor the patient's respiratory status, as well as their fluid balance and blood pressure to prevent any complications associated with the use of mechanical ventilation and critical care management.

   Ms. [**Known lastname 10607**] is a 60 y.o. F with CAD s/p IMI, CHF with EF 20%, SLE,
   scleroderma, severe pulmonary HTN, COPD on home O2, who presents with R
   hip fracture as an OSH transfer for surgery, s/p R ORIF and transferred
   to MICU for hypotension, likely multifactorial
 cardiogenic vs
   hypovolemic vs sepsis.
   # Hypotension: Resolving. Current differential include Cdiff sepsis vs
   hypovolemia (seen with LVOF obstruction on echo) vs cardiogenic shock
   (?RV compressing LV causing decreased stroke volume). Has been off
   pressors for approximately 36 hours and has responded to fluids.
   Lactates have been low and SVO2 high. Low grade fever in last 24 hours.
   CVPs hard to monitor with RV failure (which is old.) Also hct
   downtrending with unclear source of bleeding, received 2units PRBCs on
   Friday.
   - cont IVF bolus MAP>55, levophed if needed
   - IVF for low UOP
   - d/c IV flagyl, levo and IV vanco
   - continue cefepime given UCx
   - trend hct
   .
   # Respiratory:  Intubated prophylactically, known pulm htn given IVF
   needs and known CHF, on pressure support.  Needs more optimization
   before extubation
   - add Tracleer today if family can bring
   -  lasix IV prn for
 1 L

   .

   X 14 days, 125mg PO BID X 1, 125mg daily x 1 week, 125mg QOD x 1 week,

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 60-year-old woman with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20%, systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, severe pulmonary hypertension, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
- She presented with a right hip fracture and underwent right open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) surgery yesterday.
- Post-operative complications include hypotension, hypoxia, and low urine output.
- The patient was intubated for hypoxemia and is currently stable on pressure support ventilation (PSV) 5/5.
- She has a history of Clostridium difficile infection and is currently on oral vancomycin.
- The patient's fever is of unknown origin, and her urine culture showed gram-negative rods. She is also experiencing tachycardia and tachypnea.
- She has a history of multiple episodes of C. difficile, meningitis, and a small bowel obstruction that required surgery.
- The patient's current assessment includes hip fracture, post-operative hypotension and hypoxia, C. difficile infection, hypoxemia, and fever of unknown origin.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pneumonia: Given the patient's severe lung disease and the fact that she is intubated, there is a risk of developing pneumonia. Monitoring for changes in sputum color or consistency, increased respiratory

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of hip fracture and femoral neck fracture. He has been admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and shock. The patient has a fever of 101.1 degrees Fahrenheit and is experiencing hypoxemia. He is on mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode and receiving supplemental oxygen. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.1 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 109 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 125/69 mmHg to 90/51 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. 

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin level, and elevated lactate level. Other lab values are within normal range. 

The patient's physical examination reveals impaired arousal, attention, and cognition, as well as impaired ventilation. The neurologic examination is not assessed. 

The patient has multiple medical problems, including respiratory failure, shock, fever of unknown origin, hip fracture, Clostridium difficile infection, and hypotension. 

The patient is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, pain medications, and anticoagulants. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and worsening of the hip fracture.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old woman with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction (MI), congestive heart failure (CHF) with an ejection fraction of 20%, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), scleroderma, severe pulmonary hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) on home oxygen, multiple episodes of Clostridium difficile infection, and a history of small bowel obstruction (SBO) post-surgery. The patient presented with a right hip fracture and was admitted to another hospital for Clostridium difficile pan-colitis. She was discharged on oral vancomycin. Upon returning home, she had a mechanical fall resulting in a broken hip and was referred to Hospital1 for surgical correction. The operation was successful without technical complications. However, the patient experienced low to no urine output, hypoxia post-extubation, and hypotension requiring neor peripheral. An arterial line and peripheral IV were placed. The patient was transferred to the MICU for further care. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 101.1°F, blood pressure ranging from 125/69 mmHg to 90/51 mmHg, heart rate of 109 bpm, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on supplemental oxygen. The patient's heart rhythm is sinus tachycardia.

The patient presented with a right hip fracture and underwent open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) surgery yesterday. 

The patient has been experiencing hypotension and hypoxia post-operatively, which required the placement of an arterial line and peripheral intravenous (IV) access. She is currently in the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for further care. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 101.1°F, heart rate of 109 bpm, blood pressure of 125/69 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on supplemental oxygen. 

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and C-reactive protein (CRP) levels, indicating possible infection or inflammation. Blood cultures were drawn, and broad-spectrum antibiotics have been initiated.

Summary: The patient is a 60-year-old woman with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), previous inferior myocardial infarction (IMI), congestive heart failure (CHF) with an ejection fraction of 20%, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), scleroderma, severe pulmonary hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) on home oxygen, multiple episodes of Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection, meningitis in [**3-9**], prior small bowel obstruction (SBO) status post surgery, and a right hip fracture. She was admitted to another hospital for C. diff pan-colitis and discharged on oral vancomycin. Upon returning home, she experienced a mechanical fall and was found to have a broken hip. She was referred to [**Hospital1 19**] for surgical correction. She underwent right open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) yesterday afternoon. The operation was without technical complications, but there were several hours of low to no urine output. In the post-anesthesia care unit (PACU), she required a face mask for hypoxia post-extubation and was hypotensive requiring neostigmine (peripheral). An arterial line and peripheral intravenous (IV) were placed. She was transferred to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for further care. On arrival to the MICU, she was groggy, without pain, and oriented

The patient presented with a right hip fracture and was admitted to an outside hospital (OSH) for C. diff pan-colitis. She was discharged on oral vancomycin. Upon returning home, she experienced a mechanical fall and was found to have a broken hip. She was referred to Hospital1 for surgical correction and underwent open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) of the right hip yesterday afternoon. 

During the operation, the patient experienced low to no urine output and was hypoxic post-extubation, requiring a face mask. She was also hypotensive, requiring neor peripheral. An arterial line and peripheral IV were placed. She was transferred to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for further care.

Since admission, the patient's condition has been unstable. She has had a fever of 101.1 degrees Fahrenheit and has shown signs of tachycardia and tachypnea. Blood cultures

 cardiogenic vs

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient has been hypotensive but is now responding to fluids.
- There is a low-grade fever in the last 24 hours.

- The patient is on pressure support and needs more optimization before extubation.
- Started sildenafil yesterday and increased to three times a day.
- Decrease FiO2 as possible.

She underwent right open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) for the hip fracture and was transferred to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for further management.

The patient's current conditions include resolving hypotension, low-grade fever, right ventricular (RV) failure, and unclear source of bleeding. She is being treated with intravenous fluids (IVF), vasopressors, and diuretics. Her respiratory status is being closely monitored due to known pulmonary hypertension and CHF, and she is currently intubated on pressure support. The plan is to optimize her condition before considering extubation.

The patient also has a history of C. difficile infection, which was diagnosed during her previous admission. The ID recommendations include a prolonged tapering course of oral vancomycin. Additionally, she has a history of CAD, which underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) in the past. The plan is to continue antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and statin.

 cardiogenic vs

   # Hypotension: Resolving. Current differential include Cdiff sepsis vs
   hypovolemia (seen with LVOF obstruction on echo) vs cardiogenic shock
   (?RV compressing LV causing decreased stroke volume). Has been off
   pressors for approximately 36 hours and has responded to fluids.
   Lactates have been low and SVO2 high. Low grade fever in last 24 hours.
   CVPs hard to monitor with RV failure (which is old.) Also hct
   downtrending with unclear source of bleeding, received 2units PRBCs on

   - cont IVF bolus MAP>55, levophed if needed

   - continue nebs

She was previously intubated due to hypotension, likely multifactorial cardiogenic versus hypovolemic versus septic shock. The patient's hypotension has resolved, and she is now extubated. She has a low-grade fever, C. difficile infection, urinary tract infection (UTI), and a history of R hip fracture surgery.

2. Hypovolemic shock: The patient's hypotension could be attributed to hypovolemia, possibly due to internal bleeding indicated by a decreasing hematocrit level.

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of cardiovascular disease, previous inferior myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20%, systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, severe pulmonary hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease on home oxygen, who presented with a right hip fracture as an outpatient surgery transfer for surgery, subsequently underwent right open reduction and internal fixation, and was transferred to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for hypotension, likely multifactorial cardiogenic vs hypovolemic vs septic shock.

Summary of Progress:
- The patient's hypotension has resolved and she has responded to fluids.
- She has a low-grade fever in the last 24 hours.
- The patient has been extubated and is now breathing on her own.
- She has a history of urinary tract infection (UTI) and is currently being treated with ciprofloxacin.
- She also has a history of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) and is being treated with vancomycin.
- The patient has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and is on hydroxychloroquine.
- She has severe pulmonary hypertension and is on sildenafil.
- The patient has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and is on home oxygen.
- She has a history of congestive heart failure (CHF) with reduced ejection fraction.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a [age]-year-old [gender] admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. The patient's medical history includes a history of C. difficile infection, hip fracture, and previous antibiotic use. Allergies are reported to penicillins, sulfa, and aspirin. Vital signs show fever, tachycardia, and hypotension. Physical examination reveals scattered end-expiratory wheezes, diminished breath sounds at the bases, trace lower extremity edema, cyanosis in the left third toe, and right first and fifth digits. Laboratory results indicate leukocytosis with a WBC count of 17.3 K/uL, elevated lactate levels, and abnormal coagulation profiles. Imaging studies show no evidence of bowel obstruction. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with an FiO2 of 40% and is receiving IV fluids and medications. The patient's condition is complicated by urinary tract infection, impaired arousal and attention, impaired ventilation, impaired range of motion, respiratory failure, shock, fever of unknown origin, hip fracture, and hypoxemia. ICU care includes nutritional support, glycemic control, prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis and stress ulcers, and antibiotic therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently experiencing impaired ventilation and respiratory failure. Close monitoring of oxygenation and ventilation parameters is crucial to prevent further deterioration.

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), severe pulmonary hypertension (PH), chronic left ventricular (LV) diastolic dysfunction, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), scleroderma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) on home oxygen, and a recent right hip fracture that underwent open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF). The patient was admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for multifactorial distributive shock. 

Assessment and plan:
1. Shock: Resolved with transient pressor requirement and fluid resuscitation.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is stable on 40% face tent but remains tachypneic with mild right ventricular (RV) volume overload. Repeat sputum culture as prior, gentle diuresis to offload RV if tachypneic, wean O2 to maintain saturation above 92%, and use acapella valve.
3. MAT vs sinus arrhythmia: The patient's blood pressure is stable but the heart rate is suboptimally controlled. Uptitrate metoprolol to 50 mg three times daily to slow the heart rate, improve filling time, and improve cardiac output.
4. Fever: The patient is hemodynamically stable but unclear etiology. Continue ciprofloxacin (day 3-7) and continue PO vancomycin for Clostridium

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a medical history of coronary artery disease (CAD), severe pulmonary hypertension (PHTN) secondary to right heart failure, chronic left ventricular diastolic dysfunction, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), scleroderma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and previous inferior myocardial infarction (IMI). She presented to the hospital after sustaining a right hip fracture and underwent open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF). She was admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) due to multifactorial distributive shock. 

The patient's current condition includes resolved shock with transient pressor requirement and fluid resuscitation, stable respiratory status on 40% fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) but remaining tachypneic with mild right ventricular (RV) volume overload, sinus arrhythmia controlled with metoprolol, fever of unclear etiology, pulmonary hypertension secondary to right heart failure, and a history of right hip fracture with ORIF. 

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 17.3 K/uL, elevated lactate level of 1.5 mmol/L, and elevated troponin-T level of 489. The chest X-ray reveals bibasilar atelectasis without new focal consolidation.

She also has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), scleroderma, chronic left ventricular diastolic dysfunction, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and a recent right hip fracture that required open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF). The patient presented to the intensive care unit (ICU) with respiratory failure and multifactorial distributive shock. She was found to have severe pulmonary hypertension leading to right heart failure, and her condition was complicated by a urinary tract infection (UTI), fever of unknown origin, right hip fracture, and Clostridium difficile (C. difficile) infection.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status remains stable but she is occasionally tachypneic with mild right ventricular (RV) volume overload. Continuous monitoring of her respiratory status is recommended, along with gentle diuresis to offload RV if tachypneic, weaning O2 to maintain saturation between 88-94%, and using an acapella valve.
2. Shock: The patient previously experienced multifactorial distributive shock, which has resolved but may require continuous monitoring of hemodynamics and further management as needed.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) who underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to the left circumflex artery. She also has a history of severe pulmonary hypertension, chronic left ventricular diastolic dysfunction, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), scleroderma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and a recent right hip fracture that required open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF). The patient was admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for respiratory failure and distributive shock. She remains in the ICU due to various complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently stable on 40% fraction of inspired oxygen (FT), but remains tachypneic with mild right ventricular (RV) volume overload. Gentle diuresis may be considered to offload the RV if tachypnea persists. Oxygen therapy should be weaned to maintain oxygen saturation above 92%.

2. Pulmonary Hypertension: The patient has severe pulmonary hypertension secondary to her RV dysfunction. She is already on sildenafil and bosentan for this condition. Gentle diuresis may help decrease the burden on the RV.

3. Heart Failure: The patient has evidence of right heart failure due to her severe pulmonary hypertension. Diuretics may be used for volume overload, and the patient should be monitored for signs of worsening heart failure.

The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), scleroderma, coronary artery disease (CAD) status post percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to the left circumflex artery, and a recent right hip fracture treated with open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF). She was admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for respiratory failure and multifactorial distributive shock.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.3°C (99.1°F), heart rate of 108 beats per minute, blood pressure of 125/57 mmHg, respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94% on 3 liters of nasal cannula oxygen. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with an acapella valve.

Physical examination reveals scattered end-expiratory wheezes bilaterally and diminished breath sounds at the bases. The patient has trace edema in both lower extremities and cyanosis in the left third digit and right first and fifth digits. Neurological examination is unremarkable.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly decreased hemoglobin, elevated creatinine, and abnormal liver function tests. Coagulation studies reveal prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and partial thromboplastin time (PTT), with an elevated international normalized ratio (INR

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), severe pulmonary hypertension (PH), right heart failure (RHF), chronic left ventricular diastolic dysfunction (LVDD), systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), scleroderma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and a recent right hip fracture that required open reduction internal fixation (ORIF). The patient was admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for respiratory failure and multifactorial distributive shock. She is currently on mechanical ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's primary issue is respiratory failure, which has been stabilized with mechanical ventilation. However, she remains tachypneic and has mild right ventricular (RV) volume overload. Continuous monitoring of her respiratory status and weaning of oxygen to maintain oxygen saturation above 92% are recommended.

2. Heart Failure: The patient has severe pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure. Gentle diuresis may be needed to offload the RV if tachypnea persists. Long-term management with medications such as sildenafil and bosentan may also be necessary.

3. Shock: The patient experienced transient shock that resolved with fluid resuscitation and pressor support. Continuous monitoring of hemodynamics is advised to ensure stability.

4. Urinary Tract Infection

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) post percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to the left circumflex artery, severe pulmonary hypertension (PH) resulting in right heart failure, chronic left ventricular diastolic dysfunction, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), scleroderma, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) on home oxygen. The patient presented to the hospital after a right hip fracture and underwent open reduction internal fixation (ORIF). She was admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for respiratory failure and multifactorial distributive shock.

The patient's current medical issues include shock (resolved), respiratory failure, MAT vs sinus arrhythmia, fever of unclear etiology, pulmonary hypertension secondary to right heart failure, right hip fracture status post ORIF, and Clostridium difficile infection. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FT) set at 40%.

The plan includes continuing antibiotic therapy for a urinary tract infection (UTI), weaning off oxygen to maintain oxygen saturation above 92%, gentle diuresis to offload the right ventricle if tachypneic, and titrating beta-blockers to slow heart rate, improve filling time, and improve cardiac output. The patient will continue with low molecular weight heparin for deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis, proton pump inhibitor for stress ulcer prophylaxis
